instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1286: What is A1286? A1286 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2009 , Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2255, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2330, 820-2532, 820-2523, 820-2533, 820-2850, 820-2915, 820-3330..
definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.C9560: What is C9560? Tantalum capacitor on 820-2850 logic board that often dies and causes intermittent power to framebuffer PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS and PP1V8R1V55_S0GPU_ISNS_R rail, causing GPU kernel panics. Replace with non-tantalum if machine is having random black screen or kernel panics.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message:
Im having a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board, thought it was common issue with the <CAPACITOR>C9560</CAPACITOR>. replaced with 330 capacitor and it's still doing the same thing.
having shut down usually once log into OS or have all the error codes during boot up. please see attached image.
any suggestions will be apprecaited

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: I would first suspect bad RAM or a bad RAM slot.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 7398"]I would first suspect bad RAM or a bad RAM slot.[/QUOTE]

but didn't it say something fault CPU? it's not the RAMS i tried couple already and check the slot with microscope ,they all look tight and fine

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: Did you try 1 slot at a time?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: figured out, it is the ram slot! but how to fix it, it's the slot on the back side(the side with the video memory) ,can only drag solder the pins I can reach, but seems like there are still pins inside using BGA attached to the board?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message: You don't! Just max out the working slot with 8GB.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 2010 MACBOOK PRO <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1286</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> can't log in OS, shut down, CPU panics
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 7475"]You don't! Just max out the working slot with 8GB.[/QUOTE]

got it. yea I guess that's the only way to go, the guy is a picky guy and hope i can get it through by talking.
thank you man
